item.description: This vault is designed to be as bare bones as possible, and to look as good as possible in default obsidian (dark mode)‚Ä¶ However: A theme is recommended for the best/most aesthetic experience ...

item.title: Quotes - Act 1-2
item.description: Macbeth quotes act 1 Act 1, Scene 1 ‚ÄùFair is foul, and foul is fair. Hover through the fog and filthy air‚Äù The speakers are the witches, together, not speaking to anyone else It is said in the opening of the play, after they‚Äôve decided to see Macbeth after the battle is over They are saying that fair or good, will now be foul or bad it uses the literary device of a paradox helps establish the theme of good vs evil Act 1, Scene 3 ‚ÄùNot so happy, yet much happier‚Äù The witches say this to Banquo It is said when the witches first meet with Macbeth and Banquo They are saying that Banquo will not be as happy/fortunate as Macbeth, but also very happy/fortunate at the same time.

item.title: Quote 1
item.description: Macbeth Act 1 Quotes Review This is a review to help you for future quotations tests. For EACH of the following quotations from Macbeth, please answer the following: the speaker (1 mark) the context (where does the phrase occur in the plot/action?) (1 mark) the meaning (paraphrase the quote‚Äîput it into your own words) (1 mark) the significance of the quote (explain its importance through character, theme, or descriptive language (2 marks) Further questions to reflect and answers for question 4: How is the quote significant or important in terms of plot? Foreshadowing? What does this quote tell us about the character of the speaker? How does this quotation relate to a theme(s) of the play? (see Theme sheet) How does the descriptive language help us to understand what the character is saying? ACT 1 ‚ÄúThat, trusted home,/Might yet enkindle you unto the crown,/Besides the thane of Cawdor.

item.title: Quote 2-3
item.description: Macbeth Act 2 and 3 Quotes Review This is a review to help you for future quotations tests. For EACH of the following quotations from Macbeth, please answer the following: the speaker (1 mark) the context (where does the phrase occur in the plot/action?) (1 mark) the meaning (paraphrase the quote‚Äîput it into your own words) (1 mark) the significance of the quote (explain its importance through character, theme, or descriptive language) (2 marks) Further questions to reflect and answers for question 4: How is the quote significant or important in terms of plot? Foreshadowing? What does this quote tell us about the character of the speaker? How does this quotation relate to a theme(s) of the play? (see Theme sheet) How does the descriptive language help us to understand what the character is saying? Act 2 ‚ÄúIs this a dagger, which I see before me,/ The handle toward my hand? Come, let me clutch thee.
